title: Esi Edugyan, Darrel McLeod shortlisted for $5K Victoria book prize | CBC Books
text:
Esi Edugyan's novel Washington Black and Darrel McLeod's memoir Mamaskatch are up for the $5,000 City of Victoria Butler Book Prize.

The award is given annually to a writer from Greater Victoria for a work of fiction, nonfiction or poetry.

Washington Black is named for its narrator, an 11-year-old boy called "Wash" who is born into slavery on a Barbados plantation. His master is Englishman Christopher Wilde, who is obsessed with developing a machine that can fly. When a man is killed, Wilde must choose between his family and saving Black's life — and the choice results in an epic adventure around the world for Wash.

Edugyan's Washington Black won the 2018 Scotiabank Giller Prize. Television rights to the book have been purchased by 20th Century Fox TV.

McLeod's Mamaskatch is a memoir of his upbringing in Smith, Alta., raised by his fierce Cree mother Bertha who survived the residential school system. McLeod explores coming to terms with his sexuality and his sibling coming out as transgender.

Mamaskatch won the 2018 Governor General's Literary Award for nonfiction.

Kathy Page is nominated for Dear Evelyn, a historical novel about the lifetime of a marriage that begins as the Second World War breaks out. The book won the 2018 Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize.

The shortlist is rounded out by celebrated poet Lorna Crozier, who is nominated for her collection God of Shadows, and Robert Amos, up for the retrospective book E.J. Hughes Paints Vancouver Island.

The City of Victoria also announced the finalists of its $5,000 Children's Book Prize. The shortlist includes:

Sterling, Best Dog Ever by Aidan Cassie

My Life as a Diamond by Jenny Manzer

The Magic Boat by Kit Pearson & Katherine Farris, illustrated by Gabrielle Grimard

The winners will be announced on Oct. 9, 2019.
